TempSED 0.0
  • Get started
  • Reference

    Properties of the water relevant for sediment temperature modelling.

    water_properties.Rd

    water_density, water_cp, water_td , water_tc calculate the density, specific heat capacity, thermal diffusivity and thermal conductivity of water.

    water_lh estimates the latent heat of vaporization

    water_properties(T_water = 20, S = 30, P = 101325, type = 1)

water_density (T_water = 20, S = 30, P = 101325)

water_cp      (T_water = 20, S = 30, P = 101325)

water_tc      (T_water = 20, S = 30, P = 101325, type = 1)

water_td (T_water = 20, S = 30, P = 101325,
          density_water = water_density(T_water, S, P), 
          cp_water      = water_cp(T_water, S, P)) 
               
water_lh (T_water = 20, S = 30, P = 101325)

    Arguments

    T_water

    temperature of the water, one value or a vector [dgC].

    S

    salinity of the water, one value [-].

    P

    pressure, one value [Pa].

    type

    formulation for conductivity, 1 = Jamieson, 2 = Caldwell, 3 = Castelli.

    density_water

    Water density; [kg/m3], one value, or a vector of length = length of T_water.

    cp_water

    Specific heat capacity of the water ; [J/kg/dgC], one value, or a vector of length = length of T_water.

    Value

    function water_properties returns a list with:

    • density_water, the density of the water, [kg/m3], as many values as length of T_water.

    • cp_water, the specific heat capacity of the water [J/kg/dgC], length of T_water.

    • td_water, the thermal diffusivity of the water, [m2/s], length of T_water.

    • tc_water, the thermal conductivity of the water, [W/m/dg], length of T_water.

    • lh_water, the latent heat of vaporization of the water, [W/m/dg], length of T_water.

    function water_density returns a vector with the density of the water, [kg/m3], as many values as length of T_water.

    function water_cp returns a vector with the specific heat capacity of the water, [J/kg/dgC], as many values as length of T_water.

    function water_td returns a vector with the thermal diffusivity of the water, [m2/s], as many values as length of T_water.

    function water_tc returns a vector with the thermal conductivity of the water, [W/m/dg], as many values as length of T_water.

    The object attributes contain:

    • A description of these variables, including their units.

    • the input parameter settings.

    use attibutes(object)$description and attibutes(object)$parameters to extract it.

    Author

    Karline Soetaert

    Details

    See vignette("TempSED") for a description of the formulations used.

    Latent heat of vaporization is the amount of heat required to transform a unit mass from the liquid to the gaseous state.

    Specific heat is the amount of heat required to change the temperature of a mass unit of a substance by one degree; here we use Cp, the isobaric specific heat (at constant pressure)

    Thermal conductivity describes the ability to conduct heat; it is the quantity of heat transmitted due to a unit temperature gradient, through a unit thickness of a material, in a direction normal to a surface of unit area.

    Thermal diffusivity is the rate of transfer of heat of a material; a measure of how quickly a material can absorb heat from its surroundings. It can be calculated by taking the thermal conductivity divided by density and specific heat capacity at constant pressure.

    References

    general:

    Sharkawy, M.H. Lienhard,J.H., Zubair, S.M., 2010. Thermophysical properties of seawater: a review of existing correlations and data. Desalination and Water Treatment 16: 1-3, 354-380.

    K.G. Nayar, M.H. Sharqawy, L.D. Banchik, and J.H. Lienhard V, 2016, Thermophysical properties of seawater: A review and new correlations that include pressure dependence, Desalination, Vol. 390, pp.1-24. doi:10.1016/j.desal.2016.02.024

    for conductivity:

    D.T. Jamieson, and J.S. Tudhope (1970). Physical properties of seawater solutions. Thermal Conductivity, Desalination, 8, 393-401.

    D. Caldwell, (1974). Thermal conductivity of sea water. Deep Sea Research and Oceanographic Abstracts, 21(2) 131-137.

    V. Castelli, E. Stanley and E. Fischer (1974). The thermal conductivity of seawater as a function of pressure and temperature. Deep Sea Research and Oceanographic Abstracts, 21(4) 311-319.

    for density:

    F.J. Millero and A. Poisson, (1981) International one-atmosphere equation of state of seawater, Deep-Sea Research, 28A (6) 625-629.

    for specific heat capacity:

    D.T. Jamieson, J.S. Tudhope, R. Morris and G. Cartwright, (1969) Physical properties of sea water solutions: heat capacity, Desalination, 7(1) 23-30.

    See also

    air_properties. mineral_properties. bulk_properties. flux_heat.

    Examples

    
# ---------------------------------------------------------
# The defaults
# ---------------------------------------------------------

 wP <- water_properties()
 wP
#>   cp_water density_water     td_water  tc_water lh_water
#> 1 4024.879      1020.953 1.464848e-07 0.6019367  2380049
 attributes(wP)
#> $names
#> [1] "cp_water"      "density_water" "td_water"      "tc_water"     
#> [5] "lh_water"     
#> 
#> $class
#> [1] "data.frame"
#> 
#> $row.names
#> [1] 1
#> 
#> $description
#>           names                          description   units
#> 1 density_water                     density of water   kg/m3
#> 2      cp_water      specific heat capacity of water J/kg/dg
#> 3      td_water         thermal diffusivity of water    m2/s
#> 4      tc_water        thermal conductivity of water  W/m/dg
#> 5      lh_water latent heat of vaporization of water    J/kg
#> 
#> $parameters
#>     names mean.values       description units
#> 1 T_water          20 water temperature   dgC
#> 2       S          30                 S     -
#> 3       P      101325          pressure    Pa
#> 
 
 water_density()
#> [1] 1020.953
#> attr(,"description")
#>           names      description units
#> 1 density_water density of water kg/m3
#> attr(,"parameters")
#>     names mean.values       description units
#> 1 T_water          20 water temperature   dgC
#> 2       S          30                 S     -
#> 3       P      101325          pressure    Pa
 as.vector(water_density())
#> [1] 1020.953
 attributes(water_density())
#> $description
#>           names      description units
#> 1 density_water density of water kg/m3
#> 
#> $parameters
#>     names mean.values       description units
#> 1 T_water          20 water temperature   dgC
#> 2       S          30                 S     -
#> 3       P      101325          pressure    Pa
#> 

# ---------------------------------------------------------
# range of parameters
# ---------------------------------------------------------

 t.seq <- 0:50
 w.t   <- water_properties(T_water = t.seq)
 attributes(w.t)[c("description", "parameters")]
#> $description
#>           names                          description   units
#> 1 density_water                     density of water   kg/m3
#> 2      cp_water      specific heat capacity of water J/kg/dg
#> 3      td_water         thermal diffusivity of water    m2/s
#> 4      tc_water        thermal conductivity of water  W/m/dg
#> 5      lh_water latent heat of vaporization of water    J/kg
#> 
#> $parameters
#>     names mean.values       description units
#> 1 T_water          25 water temperature   dgC
#> 2       S          30                 S     -
#> 3       P      101325          pressure    Pa
#> 
 
 par (mfrow = c(2,2), las = 1)
 
 plot(t.seq, w.t$cp_water, 
      xlab = "temperature, dgC", ylab = "J/kg/K",
      main = "specific heat capacity of water") 
 
 plot(t.seq, w.t$density_water, 
      xlab = "temperature, dgC", ylab = "kg/m3",
      main = "density of water")
 
 plot(t.seq, w.t$td_water, 
      xlab = "temperature, dgC", ylab = "m2/s", 
      main = "thermal diffusivity of water")
 
 plot(t.seq, w.t$lh_water, 
      xlab = "temperature, dgC", ylab = "J/kg", 
      main= "latent heat of vaporization")
